div.p: THE TRUE COPIE OF A LETTER FROM Mr Aſhburnham, TO A FRIEND, Concerning his Deportment towards the KING in his late Attendance upon His Majeſties Perſon at Hampton-Court, and the Iſle of VVight.

div.head: The Copy of a Letter from Mr. Aſhburnham, to a Friend, &c.
div.p: I Have withheld this return too long; of which I am by ſo much the more aſhamed, by how much I found yours ſo full of kindneſſe: I will pretend to no excuſe; but if your good nature will ſuggeſt, that the deep ſenſe of my afflictions doth ſo oppreſſe my ſpirits, as it renders me altogether indiſpoſed to the leaſt intercourſe, you will be charitable, and take me right.

Would you beleeve, that to my ſorrows for the ſufferings of our deer Maſter the King, and the danger of the Publick, the generality of men in this Kingdom (and probably in many other parts too) ſhould charge mee with the ſcandal of having betrayed His Majeſtie into the Iſle of Wight, and that by compact with the Parliament and Army, before his departure from Hampton Court? And to obtain belief the better, have digeſted that their calumny into this form; That I did conſpire with them to affright His Majeſtie away from thence, that they might have the better opportunity (being at a greater diſtance from London) to deſtroy him; which to effect, the neerneſſe of that place made it very difficult, if not impoſſible: and that my reward for this ſervice hath been a great ſum of money? Thus from ſeverall hands.

Which reproach, though I never deſerved, and take my ſelf to be very much above any thing of that kinde; yet ſince there is no perſon ambitious to acquire or preſerve an honeſt reputation, but is awake, and alwayes carryes about him a tenderneſſe to the leaſt prejudice or
diminution thereof; I cannot but be touched with ſome ſenſe of that unhappy report, and give you (in whoſe good eſteem I am much concerned) the true ſtate of my part in that action, ſo far as may enable you to ſatisfie (if you meet with him) the moſt malicious perſon againſt me.

That I was commanded by their Majeſties and the Prince his Highneſſe to return into England, with Inſtructions to endeavour by the beſt means imaginable, ſuch a compliance between His Majeſty and the Army, as might have influence, and beget a right underſtanding between His Majeſtie and the Parliament, is a truth well known. That my infirmities are ſo great, and ſo publick, as that it had been better for their-ſervice to have given that imployment to ſome other of more eminent endowments, I do acknowledge with great humility: But that I did fulfill that Truſt with all induſtry and fidelity to their Majeſties, I appeal to God and them, and do not doubt but I have my portion of favour, and ſtand ſtill numbred in the Catalogue of thoſe Subjects whom they are yet pleaſed to ſtile faithfull.

What paſſed between mee and any Member either of the Parliament or Army, as it will not at all advantage His Majeſties affairs to relate; ſo will it not any way conduce to my vindication. This word I ſhall only let ſall, That a wiſer man then I, or whoever is my greateſt cenſurer, would and ought to have given credit to them, when power and intereſt accompanied with large expreſſions of good will, were the arguments and motives to gain beleef of their reall intentions. Nay truly, though His Majeſtie had known they intended nothing leſſe then the performance of thoſe duties to their Soveraigne and Country, I cannot finde (I know not what a quicker-ſighted man might have done) how in prudence his Majeſtie could have purſued any other intereſt, or made any other application then what he did, conſidering the power under which hee was: Which ſhall ſerve by way of glance at my part of negotiation in generall, becauſe even therein likewiſe I am not without ſome prejudice in many mens conceptions.

Some few weeks before his Majeſties remove from Hampton Court, there was ſcarce a day in which ſeverall alarms were not brought to his Majeſtie, by, and from very conſiderable perſons (both well affected to him, and likely to know much of what was then in agitation) of the reſolution which a violent party in the Army had to take away his life: and that ſuch a deſigne there was, there were ſtrong
inducements to perſwade; and I hope charity will be afforded to thoſe many who were and ſtill are of that belief, ſince I confeſſe my ſelf to be of that number. Which practice ſeemed to his Majeſty the more probable, for that many other particulars which were ſaid in thoſe informations to precede that action, fell out accordingly; whereupon his Majeſtie thought it not wiſdome longer to deſpiſe the poſſible means left him for the prevention of that danger, and therefore reſolved to retire himſelf from thence, but with this poſitive intention, not to deſert this Kingdom, either by croſſing the Seas, or going into Scotland. The reaſons his Majeſtie gave, you will pardon me if I deliver not, and ſuſpend your Cenſure, in caſe your judgement invite you to oppoſe that reſult, till you hear the weight of them, and I will ingage the little credit the world hath left me, you ſhall be ſatisfied.

And what man is hee, who hath the leaſt grain of underſtanding, bears about him any affections either to his ſacred Perſon, or to the Common good, hath any regard to his own duty or reputation, would have taken upon him to diſſwade his Majeſtie from what he had then reſolved on, and thereby expoſed himſelf both to the danger and guilt of that miſchief, which ſo many had forewarned him of, and was ſo likely to happen? Sure I am, if I had been that man, I ſhould have thought my ſelf juſtly to have merited the Character of unfaithfulneſſe, which is now ſo injuriouſly caſt upon me.

It reſted then that his Majeſtie was to make choice of a place, where he might avoid the preſent danger, where he might give leaſt offence to the intereſt of the Parliament and Army, where he might have frequent intercourſe with both, for ſetling a Peace (of which he then deſpaired not;) and laſtly, where he might moſt ſecurely (and the meaſure of ſafety was, where there were no Souldiers) expect the abatement of the ruinous power of the Levellers and their faction, to be the fruits of the General Rendezvous, which was immediately to follow.

Upon theſe grounds, his Majeſtie thought the Iſle of Wight moſt proper for his reſidence, eſpecially if he could obtain honourable Conditions from the Governour of that place; to whom (when his Majeſtie was come within twenty miles) he commanded Sir John Berkeley and my ſelf to repair, and make trial of what Reception we could procure for him; who, after ſome conſideration of what we propoſed, proffered this Engagement, [That ſince it appeared his Majestie
came from Hampton-Court to ſave his life, if he pleaſed to put himſelf inte his hands, whatever he could expect from a perſon of honour or honeſty, his Majeſtie ſhould have it made good by him:] which truely to us ſeemed ſufficient; and I do for my own part acknowledge, my confidence was, that, by that Engagement, he would not have laid any reſtraint upon his Majeſtie, nor have given acceſſe to any Souldiers into that Iſland: But how honourably and how faithfully he hath performed his promiſed duty to the King, you are as good a witneſſe as my ſelf; and therefore, as I take little pleaſure in the memory of it, ſo there will be little ſatisfaction to you in the repeating it: it ſhall ſuffice that I have now been taught, that Honour and Honeſty have clear contrary definitions in ſeveral mens underſtandings.

For the election his Majeſtie made of the Iſle of Wight, upon the grounds before mentioned, as therewith I did then concur, ſo (with reſpect to their judgements who are otherwiſe perſwaded) I do ſtill believe it was (as his affairs then ſtood) the beſt of any place which he could make choice of: And I will not be afraid to avow my opinion, becauſe ſucceſſe hath made it ſeem leſſe reaſonable; which being taken out of the Scale, and all circumſtances worthy debate before his departure from Hampton-Court, conſidered; perhaps wiſer men then choſe, who in that preſume to condemn his Majeſties judgement, may yet approve of that choice. However, his Majeſtie was reſolved to go from Hampton-Court; and, I know not what other mens cuſtoms are, I cannot but be well ſatisfied with my own, which hath been ever ready to ſubmit, when his Majeſtie hath been willing to command; and I ſhould account it a great misfortune to me, that his commands ſhould be ſuch, to which I ſhould think fit rather with humility to oppoſe my reaſons, then with cheerfulneſs to obey his pleaſure; but that ſtraight hath never yet happened, nor (I am confident) ever will: ſo careful is his Majeſtie to impoſe nothing upon any man, but what he believes juſt and lawful.

That any Member of the Parliament or Army had any knowledge by me of his Majeſties removal from Hampton-Court, or that any Compact between me and any of them was ever made, to the diſſervice of his Majeſtie in any particular whatſoever, I provoke them and all the world to produce the leaſt colour of proof, and deſire that no man would ſpare me more then I ſhould do ſuch whom I found guilty of ſo baſe a crime; and ſhall not ſtick to invite them to it, who have
been ſo liberal in blaſting my reputation, when I may live with that freedom they do, which either their greater wiſdom, or their leſſe loyalty then mine, hath purchaſed. In the mean time, it is ſome comfort to me to finde theſe cenſurers to be men but of ſuch diſpoſitions, as will hazard no more then onely their good wiſhes for his Majeſtie; and for ſuch I take them, and for ſuch leave them.

If I ſhould tell theſe ſevere judges of other mens actions, that his Majeſties preſent perſonal condition is the ſame in the Iſle of Wight, with what it was when he left Hampton-Court, they would perhaps wonder at me, but upon examination finde it truth: for before his Majeſties coming from thence (at leaſt ſix days) he was forbidden riding abroad, and confined within the limits of that place.

And if any man can aſſure me, that if his Majeſtie had continued at Hampton-Court, the Parliament would not have preſented theſe four Bills to him, or that they being preſented, his Majeſties refuſing to make them Laws, ſhould not have drawn on his late reſtraint, or the later Votes of Parliament concerning farther application to his Majeſtie, I ſhall then (for indeed I take that to be the cauſe of his relapſe) with great lowlineſſe of ſpirit acknowledge my ſelf to have been an unhappie (though not an unfaithful) inſtrument in his Majeſties remove from Hampton-Court: But till then, my ſufferings in theſe ſcandals may be continued, but my opinion not changed, nor the quietneſſe of my minde diſturbed, for having in that action diſcharged my duty to his Majeſtie.

As for the money I ſhould have received for betraying his Majeſtie, if none of my Calumniators have more to ſubſiſt on, then I have had either from Parliament or Army, they would be in worſe condition, then (notwithſtanding all their malice to me) I wiſh them. In earneſt, it would better have become thoſe who firſt deſigned me this infamy, to have made choice of ſome, who had a mark upon them for doing ſome action, which may at leaſt be of kin to the accuſation, though but between fellow-ſubjects: but you will pardon my vanity, if I ſay I abhor ſuch unworthineſſe, and defie mankinde to bring the leaſt blemiſh of that nature in judgement againſt me.

I have done, when I have told you, that I have heard Divines ſay, that God doth moſt puniſh us in thoſe things we moſt prize, and think our ſelves moſt concerned: I ſhall therefore hope to make a religious uſe of theſe aſperſions caſt upon my integrity: for I fear I did
glory too much in my honour of faithfulneſſe and loyalty to his Majeſtie, and did not thankfully conſider (as I ought to have done) that it was the bleſſing of God which enabled me to go thorow with the performance of my duty in his ſervice.

If men would but as well think upon the ſolicitude and care of their mindes, who are honoured with neer relations to the ſervice of great Princes, as they look upon the advantages which thereby Fortune may caſt upon them, they would finde more cauſe to pity them for their labour and hazards (which is ordinarily beyond their capacities to fathom, who are at very remote diſtance) then to envie them for their honour or profit. But ſince of all evils ſeated in the heart of man, Malice hath the greateſt dominion, it were vain for Vertue it ſelf to hope for freedom from thoſe effects which naturally ariſe from it; and much more for me, who though in this particular have as much innocence to protect me, as can be conſiſtent with mortality, yet in other things which may be imputed to weakneſs, and unskilfulneſs in matters of great concernment, I do with all ingenuity confeſſe, no man carries a greater weight of guilt then he whoſe care it is, to preſerve unſpotted the reputation of an honeſt man, thereby to retain ſtill the favour and affection, wherewith you have conſtantly honoured,

closer.signed: Your moſt faithful, and moſt humble ſervant, John Aſhburnham.
